chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the normal distribution table to solve for the different probabilities.

Since we are solving for the probability of a price doubling up, we will use $X=100\%$. Substituting these values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
Z&=\dfrac{100-16.6}{31.9}\\[15 pt]
&=2.61
\end{aligned}$$

Using a Z-score table, we can see that a Z-score of $2.61$ is equivalent to $0.9955$. However, since we are looking at the right-tail of the standard distribution curve, we still need to subtract this value form $1$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Probability}&=1-0.9955\\
&=0.0045
\end{aligned}$$

The probability of the price doubling up is $0.0045$ or $0.45\%$

To get the probability of a price going triple, we can use $X=200\%$. Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
Z&=\dfrac{200-16.6}{31.9}\\[15 pt]
&=5.75
\end{aligned}$$
Using a Z-score table, we can see that the price tripling up is not probable since the probability value from this Z-score is negligible.
